KU-TP 070

The path integral of unimodular gravity

R. de León Ardóna,b,111e-mail address: rdeleon@sissa.it N. Ohta,c,d,222e-mail address: ohtan@phys.kindai.ac.jp and R. Percaccia,b,333e-mail address: percacci@sissa.it

aInternational School for Advanced Studies, via Bonomea 265, 34136 Trieste, Italy

bINFN, Sezione di Trieste, Italy

cDepartment of Physics, Kindai University, Higashi-Osaka, Osaka 577-8502, Japan

dMaskawa Institute for Science and Culture, Kyoto Sangyo University, Kyoto 603-8555, Japan

Abstract

We compute the one-loop effective action in unimodular gravity, starting from two different classical formulations of the theory. We find that the effective action is the same in both cases, and agrees with the one of General Relativity.

1 Introduction

Unimodular Gravity (UG) is a reformulation of General Relativity (GR) where the determinant of the metric is fixed a priori and is not subjected to variation [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. The difference between these two theories is very subtle, since in GR the determinant of the metric changes under diffeomorphisms and in particular can be fixed locally to have a predetermined form. One could thus see UG as a particular gauge-fixed version of GR. Indeed, the equations of motion of the two theories are identical. The only substantial difference, which is also the reason for the recent interest in UG, is the status of the cosmological constant: a coupling in the Lagrangian of GR, and an integration constant in UG. As a consequence, it is expected that the problems of the cosmological constant appears differently in the two theories, especially when quantum effects are taken into account [6, 7, 8].

At the classical level the two theories are “almost” equivalent, in the sense that they only differ by the status of a single global scaling mode of the metric [5]. (We will not consider this important subtlety in this paper, so by equivalence we will always mean “almost equivalence”.) The question then arises whether UG and GR are also equivalent at the quantum level.

As a concrete way of addressing this question, we set out to straightforwardly compare the divergent part of the effective action for UG and GR, both computed using the conventional one loop background field method. It is known that the same coefficients appearing in the logarithmically divergent part also appear in certain finite nonlocal terms in the effective action. Thus, different logarithmic divergences imply physical inequivalence of the two theories.

There is no single unambiguous way to construct a quantum theory from a classical one, and the answer may well depend on the starting point and on details of the procedure followed. The authors of ([7, 8, 9]) argue in favor of equivalence, possibly with qualifications. On the other hand [10] undertook the calculation of logarithmic divergences in UG and found a different result from GR. This conclusion is also implicit in [11, 12, 13].

There are several ways of formulating UG. We shall start from the most straightforward one, which imposes the unimodularity constraint on the determinant of the metric. Actually, given that we want to allow the metric to be dimensionful, we cannot simply set |g|=1𝑔1|g|=1. A more general statement is to fix a volume form

ω​ϵμ1​…​μd​d​xμ1∧…∧d​xμd,𝜔subscriptitalic-ϵsubscript𝜇1…subscript𝜇𝑑𝑑superscript𝑥subscript𝜇1…𝑑superscript𝑥subscript𝜇𝑑\omega\,\epsilon_{\mu_{1}\ldots\mu_{d}}\,dx^{\mu_{1}}\wedge\ldots\wedge dx^{\mu_{d}}\ , (1.1)

not related to the dynamical metric g𝑔g, and to require

|g|=ω.𝑔𝜔\sqrt{|g|}=\omega\ . (1.2)

The function ω𝜔\omega is a scalar density of weight one. In the following we shall use the background field method to construct the path integral for gravity, and the background metric g¯μ​νsubscript¯𝑔𝜇𝜈\bar{g}_{\mu\nu} will be assumed to be unimodular in the same sense, namely |g¯|=ω¯𝑔𝜔\sqrt{|\bar{g}|}=\omega.

The action of Unimodular Gravity (UG) is

SU​G​(g)=ZN​∫dd​x​ω​RwhereZN=116​π​G.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑈𝐺𝑔subscript𝑍𝑁superscript𝑑𝑑𝑥𝜔𝑅wheresubscript𝑍𝑁116𝜋𝐺S_{UG}(g)=Z_{N}\int d^{d}x\,\omega\,R\qquad\mathrm{where}\qquad Z_{N}=\frac{1}{16\pi G}\ . (1.3)

∇μϵμ=0.subscript∇𝜇superscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇0\nabla_{\mu}\epsilon^{\mu}=0\ . (1.4)

Note that when one varies the action (1.3), the term gμ​ν​δ​Rμ​ν=∇μΩμsuperscript𝑔𝜇𝜈𝛿subscript𝑅𝜇𝜈subscript∇𝜇superscriptΩ𝜇g^{\mu\nu}\delta R_{\mu\nu}=\nabla_{\mu}\Omega^{\mu} can be discarded as in GR, since equation (1.2) implies that ∇ω=0∇𝜔0\nabla\omega=0, and ∇∇\nabla can be integrated by parts as usual. In particular, when δ​gμ​ν=∇μϵν+∇νϵμ𝛿subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈subscript∇𝜇subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜈subscript∇𝜈subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇\delta g_{\mu\nu}=\nabla_{\mu}\epsilon_{\nu}+\nabla_{\nu}\epsilon_{\mu} invariance of the action under 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} follows from integrations by parts, the Bianchi identity and (1.4). For discussions of more general 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff}-invariant theories of gravity see [14, 15, 16].

There exist local coordinate systems where ω𝜔\omega is constant. Then, in the case when the coordinates are chosen to have dimension of length, one can set ω=1𝜔1\omega=1, and the metric would be unimodular in the proper sense of the word. We will stick to the standard terminology and call UG a theory where (1.2) holds, even when ω𝜔\omega is not a pure number and not constant.

The constraint (1.2) could be imposed by adding to (1.3) a term containing a Lagrange multiplier, multiplied by |g|−ω𝑔𝜔\sqrt{|g|}-\omega. This, however, would complicate the calculation of radiative corrections. Since in practice the functional integration measure is defined on the fluctuation field anyway, a simpler alternative is to use an exponential parametrization for the background field expansion [17, 11, 18, 19]

gμ​ν=g¯μ​ρ(eX)ρνg_{\mu\nu}=\bar{g}_{\mu\rho}(e^{X})^{\rho}{}_{\nu} (1.5)

and demand that Xρ=νg¯ρ​σhσ​νX^{\rho}{}_{\nu}=\bar{g}^{\rho\sigma}h_{\sigma\nu} be traceless. This automatically enforces unimodularity of gμ​νsubscript𝑔𝜇𝜈g_{\mu\nu}, and tracelessness is a linear condition that can be straightforwardly imposed on the quantum field, without using Lagrange multipliers. We will refer to this formulation as “minimal” UG.

An alternative formulation consists in writing the action in terms of an unrestricted dynamical metric γμ​νsubscript𝛾𝜇𝜈\gamma_{\mu\nu}, conformally related to gμ​νsubscript𝑔𝜇𝜈g_{\mu\nu}:

gμ​ν=γμ​ν​(|γ|ω2)m.subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈subscript𝛾𝜇𝜈superscript𝛾superscript𝜔2𝑚g_{\mu\nu}=\gamma_{\mu\nu}\left(\frac{|\gamma|}{\omega^{2}}\right)^{m}\ . (1.6)

Note that the fraction is a genuine scalar, so that both g𝑔g and γ𝛾\gamma are proper tensors, and the standard formulae for the curvatures of conformally related metric can be applied. For m=−1/d𝑚1𝑑m=-1/d the metric gμ​νsubscript𝑔𝜇𝜈g_{\mu\nu} automatically satisfies the constraint (1.2). Then, we can take γ𝛾\gamma as the fundamental dynamical variable and write the action [14, 15]

=\displaystyle= ZN​∫dd​x​|γ|1/d​ωd−2d​[R​[γ]+(d−1)​(d−2)4​d2​(|γ|−1​∇|γ|−2​ω−1​∇ω)2],subscript𝑍𝑁superscript𝑑𝑑𝑥superscript𝛾1𝑑superscript𝜔𝑑2𝑑delimited-[]𝑅delimited-[]𝛾𝑑1𝑑24superscript𝑑2superscriptsuperscript𝛾1∇𝛾2superscript𝜔1∇𝜔2\displaystyle Z_{N}\int d^{d}x\,|\gamma|^{1/d}\omega^{\frac{d-2}{d}}\left[R[\gamma]+\frac{(d-1)(d-2)}{4d^{2}}\left(|\gamma|^{-1}\nabla|\gamma|-2\omega^{-1}\nabla\omega\right)^{2}\right]\ ,

where ∇∇\nabla are the covariant derivatives constructed with γμ​νsubscript𝛾𝜇𝜈\gamma_{\mu\nu}.555Recall that under 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} the determinant |g|𝑔|g| is a scalar, so ∇μ|g|=∂μ|g|subscript∇𝜇𝑔subscript𝜇𝑔\nabla_{\mu}|g|=\partial_{\mu}|g|. This action is invariant under 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} as well as an additional Weyl group acting as

γμ​ν→Ω2​γμ​ν;ω→ω,formulae-sequence→subscript𝛾𝜇𝜈superscriptΩ2subscript𝛾𝜇𝜈→𝜔𝜔\gamma_{\mu\nu}\to\Omega^{2}\gamma_{\mu\nu}\ ;\qquad\omega\to\omega\ , (1.8)

which leaves the metric gμ​νsubscript𝑔𝜇𝜈g_{\mu\nu} invariant.

These two formulations differ in the way in which a scalar degree of freedom is removed: either by imposing a constraint or by the presence of a gauge freedom. They are classically equivalent. In this paper we compute the one-loop divergences of UG in both formulations, and we shall see that the results are the same, and also agree with those of GR.

We mention here another motivation for this calculation, which actually prompted our initial interest in this problem. In [20] we computed the gravitational divergences of GR using as dynamical variable a metric γμ​νsubscript𝛾𝜇𝜈\gamma_{\mu\nu} defined as in (1.6) (with ω=1𝜔1\omega=1) in the generic case m≠−1/d𝑚1𝑑m\not=-1/d. (This was later generalized to higher-derivative gravity in [21].) All the calculations were performed with a standard gauge-fixing term depending on two parameters α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta. Furthermore, the parametrization of the metric depended on two parameters m𝑚m and ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi (the latter was called ω𝜔\omega in [20, 21], but we use here a different notation in order not to confuse it with the fixed volume form ω𝜔\omega). The results were found to be the same independently of α𝛼\alpha, β𝛽\beta and ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi in the limit m→−1/d→𝑚1𝑑m\to-1/d, and independent of α𝛼\alpha, β𝛽\beta and m𝑚m in the case when ϖ=1/2italic-ϖ12\varpi=1/2, which corresponds to using the exponential parametrization for the metric. In these two cases there was an enhanced gauge-independence. However, the calculations in those papers did not cover the unimodular case m→−1/d→𝑚1𝑑m\to-1/d, because our gauge fixing was not complete in that case due to the additional Weyl invariance. There remained therefore the task of calculating the divergences directly in the unimodular theory, to see whether they agree with the limit m→−1/d→𝑚1𝑑m\to-1/d or not. This is what we will do here.

The calculation of the one-loop divergences requires that we write the one-loop effective action as a path integral, which can be expressed as a product of determinants. In the minimal formulation, a simple argument seems to suggest that the path integrals of UG and GR should be different. Classical UG is GR where we have partially fixed the gauge by fixing the determinant of the metric or, at the linearized level, we have set the trace of the fluctuation to zero. This partial gauge fixing requires a scalar “ghost” determinant [18]. On the other hand when we quantize UG the condition h=0ℎ0h=0 is already present at the classical level and there is no need to introduce a ghost. The remaining gauge freedom can be fixed in the same way, so there seems to be a net difference of a scalar determinant. This argument is wrong, for reasons that will appear in section 3.2. However, it points to subtleties in the definition of the path integral. For this reason we consider first the Hamiltonian definition of the path integral, which is more fundamental. In section 2 we will calculate the path integrals of linearized GR and UG in certain gauges where they are explicitly seen to be the same. It will be enough to do this on a flat background. Unfortunately the Hamiltonian formalism is not well-suited to discuss covariant gauges. In section 3 we calculate the one-loop effective actions of GR and UG by covariant methods. The main point here will be identifying the proper way of factoring the volume of the gauge group 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff}. We construct the proper gauge-fixed path integral for UG and find that it agrees, in a well-defined sense, with the one of GR. Section 4 contains some comments and conclusions.

2 Hamiltonian analysis of GR and minimal UG

2.1 Linearized GR

In this section we prove, based on constrained Hamiltonian formalism, that the path integrals of GR and UG contain the same determinants. Insofar as the Lagrangian path integral is derived from the Hamiltonian one, this proof is somewhat more fundamental. For our purpose it is going to be enough to consider the case of a flat background. Then GR reduces to the Fierz-Pauli theory with Lagrangian density

ℒ=−12​∂αhμ​ν​∂αhμ​ν+∂αhμ​∂βα⁡hμ​β−∂αhμ​∂μα⁡h+12​∂αh​∂αh.ℒ12subscript𝛼subscriptℎ𝜇𝜈superscript𝛼superscriptℎ𝜇𝜈subscript𝛼subscriptℎ𝜇superscriptsubscript𝛽𝛼superscriptℎ𝜇𝛽subscript𝛼subscriptℎ𝜇superscriptsuperscript𝜇𝛼ℎ12subscript𝛼ℎsuperscript𝛼ℎ{\cal L}=-\frac{1}{2}\partial_{\alpha}h_{\mu\nu}\partial^{\alpha}h^{\mu\nu}+\partial_{\alpha}h_{\mu}{}^{\alpha}\partial_{\beta}h^{\mu\beta}-\partial_{\alpha}h_{\mu}{}^{\alpha}\partial^{\mu}h+\frac{1}{2}\partial_{\alpha}h\partial^{\alpha}h\ . (2.1)

Their preservation leads to d𝑑d secondary constraints

There are no further constraints, and all constraints are first class. We then have to gauge fix the system. We can take the gauge fixing conditions

The situation is very simple, because each gauge condition is conjugate to one of the constraints. 2.2 Linearized minimal UG

UG in minimal formulation corresponds to just setting h=0ℎ0h=0 in (2.1), which effectively just removes the last two terms. In terms of the variables introduced in the preceding section, the constraint h=0ℎ0h=0 implies 2​ϕ+t=02italic-ϕ𝑡02\phi+t=0. Using this in (2.15), one finds

Equations (2.34), (2.36), (2.37) and (2.39) can be solved for the velocities h˙i​jT​Tsubscriptsuperscript˙ℎ𝑇𝑇𝑖𝑗\dot{h}^{TT}_{ij}, ζ˙isubscript˙𝜁𝑖\dot{\zeta}_{i}, Φ˙˙Φ\dot{\Phi} and t˙˙𝑡\dot{t}, whereas (2.35) and (2.38) give d−1𝑑1d-1 primary constraints

Taking Poisson brackets with the Hamiltonian one obtains d−1𝑑1d-1 secondary constraints

Siv​T=Πiζ,Sv=∂2Πt.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑣𝑇𝑖subscriptsuperscriptΠ𝜁𝑖superscript𝑆𝑣superscript2superscriptΠ𝑡S^{vT}_{i}=\Pi^{\zeta}_{i}\ ,\qquad S^{v}=\partial^{2}\Pi^{t}\ . (2.41)

The first of these commutes with the Hamiltonian and is therefore automatically conserved. The second, however, generates a “tertiary” constraint

Tv=∂2∂2Φ,superscript𝑇𝑣superscript2superscript2ΦT^{v}=\partial^{2}\partial^{2}\Phi\ , (2.42)

which is ∂2superscript2\partial^{2} times the second constraint in (2.23). Its Poisson bracket with the Hamiltonian is weakly zero, so there are no further constraints. All the constraints commute with each others and form a first class system. Their total number is one less than in Fierz-Pauli theory.

We can impose the following gauge fixing conditions:

viT=0,v=0,ζi=0,t=0,ΠΦ=0.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑇0formulae-sequence𝑣0formulae-sequencesubscript𝜁𝑖0formulae-sequence𝑡0superscriptΠΦ0\displaystyle v_{i}^{T}=0\ ,\qquad v=0\ ,\qquad\zeta_{i}=0\ ,\qquad t=0\ ,\qquad\Pi^{\Phi}=0\ . (2.43)

Let us order all the constraints as ϕa=(Civ​T,Cv,Siv​T,Sv,Tv)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎subscriptsuperscript𝐶𝑣𝑇𝑖superscript𝐶𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝑆𝑣𝑇𝑖superscript𝑆𝑣superscript𝑇𝑣\phi_{a}=(C^{vT}_{i},C^{v},S^{vT}_{i},S^{v},T^{v}) and all gauge conditions as χa=(viT,v,ζi,t,ΠΦ)subscript𝜒𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑇𝑣subscript𝜁𝑖𝑡superscriptΠΦ\chi_{a}=(v_{i}^{T},v,\zeta_{i},t,\Pi^{\Phi}). Therefore

detMU​G=(det(−∂2))3.subscript𝑀𝑈𝐺superscriptsuperscript23\det M_{UG}=(\det(-\partial^{2}))^{3}\ . (2.44)

The time conservation of the gauge constraints fixes the Lagrange multipliers in the Hamiltonian. When this is done, one finds that the gauge-fixed Hamiltonian is again equal to (2.26).

In these “unitary” gauges, the two path integrals are the same.

3 One loop effective actions

The general framework for our calculations is the same as in [21]. In view of application to UG we restrict ourselves to the exponential parametrization (1.5).

The symmetric tensor hμ​νsubscriptℎ𝜇𝜈h_{\mu\nu} is subjected to the York decomposition

hμ​ν=hμ​νTT+∇¯μ​ξν+∇¯ν​ξμ+(∇¯μ​∇¯ν−1d​g¯μ​ν​∇¯2)​σ+1d​g¯μ​ν​h,subscriptℎ𝜇𝜈subscriptsuperscriptℎTT𝜇𝜈subscript¯∇𝜇subscript𝜉𝜈subscript¯∇𝜈subscript𝜉𝜇subscript¯∇𝜇subscript¯∇𝜈1𝑑subscript¯𝑔𝜇𝜈superscript¯∇2𝜎1𝑑subscript¯𝑔𝜇𝜈ℎh_{\mu\nu}=h^{\mathrm{TT}}_{\mu\nu}+\bar{\nabla}_{\mu}\xi_{\nu}+\bar{\nabla}_{\nu}\xi_{\mu}+\left(\bar{\nabla}_{\mu}\bar{\nabla}_{\nu}-\frac{1}{d}\bar{g}_{\mu\nu}\bar{\nabla}^{2}\right)\sigma+\frac{1}{d}\bar{g}_{\mu\nu}h\,, (3.1)

where

∇¯μ​hμ​νTT=0,g¯μ​ν​hμ​νTT=0,∇¯μ​ξμ=0,h=g¯μ​ν​hμ​ν.formulae-sequencesuperscript¯∇𝜇subscriptsuperscriptℎTT𝜇𝜈0formulae-sequencesuperscript¯𝑔𝜇𝜈subscriptsuperscriptℎTT𝜇𝜈0formulae-sequencesuperscript¯∇𝜇subscript𝜉𝜇0ℎsuperscript¯𝑔𝜇𝜈subscriptℎ𝜇𝜈\bar{\nabla}^{\mu}h^{\mathrm{TT}}_{\mu\nu}=0\,,\,\,\,\,\bar{g}^{\mu\nu}h^{\mathrm{TT}}_{\mu\nu}=0\,,\,\,\,\,\bar{\nabla}^{\mu}\xi_{\mu}=0\,,\,\,\,\,h=\bar{g}^{\mu\nu}h_{\mu\nu}\,. (3.2)

We will expand the action around an Einstein background R¯μ​ν=R¯d​g¯μ​νsubscript¯𝑅𝜇𝜈¯𝑅𝑑subscript¯𝑔𝜇𝜈\bar{R}_{\mu\nu}=\frac{\bar{R}}{d}\bar{g}_{\mu\nu}. In GR, an Einstein metric automatically satisfies the tracefree part of the Einstein equations with cosmological constant. The remaining trace equation is E=0𝐸0E=0, where

In UG this equation is not present, so an Einstein background is automatically on shell.

We note that the change of variables (3.15) has unit Jacobian.

The (background-)gauge invariance of the Faddeev-Popov determinant and of the classical action leads by the standard procedure to the factorization of the volume of the gauge group

V𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓=∫(d​ϵ).subscript𝑉𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑑italic-ϵV_{\mathit{Diff}}=\int(d\epsilon)\ . (3.17)

This factor is usually dropped, but we will keep it explicit here for later reference.

The partition function is the product of determinants coming from all the fields, ghosts and from the Jacobians. Several determinants (among them all the scalar determinants, and in particular the β𝛽\beta-dependent ones) cancel, and the partition function is independent of the gauge choice:

ZG​R=V𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓​e−S​(g¯)​Det1​(ΔL​1−2​R¯d)1/2Det2​(ΔL​2−2​R¯d)1/2.subscript𝑍𝐺𝑅subscript𝑉𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓superscript𝑒𝑆¯𝑔subscriptDet1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿12¯𝑅𝑑12subscriptDet2superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿22¯𝑅𝑑12Z_{GR}=V_{\mathit{Diff}}e^{-S(\bar{g})}\frac{{\rm Det}_{1}\left(\Delta_{L1}-\frac{2\bar{R}}{d}\right)^{1/2}}{{\rm Det}_{2}\left(\Delta_{L2}-\frac{2\bar{R}}{d}\right)^{1/2}}\ . (3.18)

This formula explicitly agrees with (2.32) when the background is flat: aside from the field-independent prefactor, the determinant on transverse vectors contributes Det​□(d−1)/2Detsuperscript□𝑑12{\rm Det}\Box^{(d-1)/2} while that on transverse tracefree tensors contributes Det​□−(d−2)​(d+1)/4Detsuperscript□𝑑2𝑑14{\rm Det}\Box^{-(d-2)(d+1)/4}. The powers of the determinants thus correctly count the number of physical degrees freedom of the theory.

We note that in the limit β→∞→𝛽\beta\to\infty, χ→ΔL0−1​h→𝜒superscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿01ℎ\chi\to{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{-1}h and the second term in (3.14) imposes h=0ℎ0h=0 strongly. This is equivalent to removing by hand hℎh from the linearized action and adding a ghost term detΔL0subscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0\sqrt{\det{\Delta_{L}}_{0}}, a procedure that was called “unimodular gauge” in [18]. This leaves a residual gauge freedom parametrized by the transverse vecorfields ϵμTsubscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇𝜇\epsilon^{T}_{\mu}, that can be gauge-fixed by setting ξμ=0subscript𝜉𝜇0\xi_{\mu}=0, or by adding a suitable gauge-fixing term of a type that we shall discuss in the next section.

3.2 One-loop UG in minimal formulation

Let us now discuss UG in the minimal formulation. We impose h=0ℎ0h=0 at the classical level, before defining the functional integral. Then we have to gauge fix 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff}, which is generated by vector fields satisfying

∇¯μ​ϵμ=0.subscript¯∇𝜇superscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇0\bar{\nabla}_{\mu}\epsilon^{\mu}=0\ . (3.19)

Lμ=ν∇¯μ1∇¯2∇¯ν;Tμ=νδνμ−LμνL^{\mu}{}_{\nu}=\bar{\nabla}^{\mu}\frac{1}{\bar{\nabla}^{2}}\bar{\nabla}_{\nu}\ ;\qquad T^{\mu}{}_{\nu}=\delta^{\mu}_{\nu}-L^{\mu}{}_{\nu} (3.20)

be the longitudinal and transverse projectors defined relative to the background metric. We choose our gauge-fixing function as 666It may be better to have a local gauge-fixing condition. Ultimately the additional determinant is canceled by a Nielsen-kallosh ghost term, so that the final result is the same. In the linearized Hilbert action, due to h=0ℎ0h=0, we can replace s𝑠s by ΔL0​σsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0𝜎{\Delta_{L}}_{0}\sigma. The determinants work out as in GR, except that one scalar determinant coming from the integration over σ𝜎\sigma remains uncanceled because of the absence of the scalar ghost. Collecting all the determinants, the partition function of unimodular gravity is

ZU​G=(∫(d​ϵT))​e−S​(g¯)​Det1​(ΔL​1−2​R¯d)1/2Det2​(ΔL​2−2​R¯d)1/2​Det​ΔL01/2.subscript𝑍𝑈𝐺𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇superscript𝑒𝑆¯𝑔subscriptDet1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿12¯𝑅𝑑12subscriptDet2superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿22¯𝑅𝑑12DetsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012Z_{UG}=\left(\int(d\epsilon^{T})\right)e^{-S(\bar{g})}\frac{{\rm Det}_{1}\left(\Delta_{L1}-\frac{2\bar{R}}{d}\right)^{1/2}}{{\rm Det}_{2}\left(\Delta_{L2}-\frac{2\bar{R}}{d}\right)^{1/2}{\rm Det}{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{1/2}}\ . (3.25)

It would be tempting at this point to interpret the first term on the r.h.s. as the volume of 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} and to drop it from the partition function. One would then conclude that the partition function of UG differs from that of GR by a scalar determinant. This, however, cannot be correct. It would mean that there is an additional scalar physical degree of freedom, in contrast to the result of the Hamiltonian analysis (2.45).

The key to a correct definition of the path integral is the requirement that the volume of the gauge group, that one factors and discards, has to be independent of the metric. At the formal level of this discussion, all integrals over differentially unconstrained fields such as ∫(d​ϵ)𝑑italic-ϵ\int(d\epsilon) are metric-independent. Since the definition of a transverse vector depends on the metric, the integral ∫(d​ϵT)𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇\int(d\epsilon^{T}) cannot be treated as a metric-independent constant. This suggests that the measure of the group 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} must contain some determinant. After all, we note that already the volume of 𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{Diff}, when written in terms of the transverse and longitudinal gauge parameters,contains a determinant. In fact from (3.5) we find that

(d​ϵ)=(d​ϵT)​(d​ϕ)​Det​ΔL01/2.𝑑italic-ϵ𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇𝑑italic-ϕDetsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012(d\epsilon)=(d\epsilon^{T})(d\phi){\rm Det}{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{1/2}\ . (3.26)

One could define the volume of 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} as the integral ∫(d​ϵ)𝑑italic-ϵ\int(d\epsilon) with a delta function δ​(∇μϵμ)𝛿subscript∇𝜇superscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇\delta(\nabla_{\mu}\epsilon^{\mu}).777We thank D. Benedetti for this remark. Using (3.26) and ∇μϵμ=−ΔL0​ϕsubscript∇𝜇superscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇subscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0italic-ϕ\nabla_{\mu}\epsilon^{\mu}=-{\Delta_{L}}_{0}\phi, we find that integrating a function that is independent of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi

∫(d​ϵ)​δ​(∇μϵμ)𝑑italic-ϵ𝛿subscript∇𝜇superscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇\displaystyle\int(d\epsilon)\delta(\nabla_{\mu}\epsilon^{\mu}) =\displaystyle= ∫(d​ϵT)​(d​ϕ)​Det​ΔL01/2​δ​(ΔL0​ϕ)𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇𝑑italic-ϕDetsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012𝛿subscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0italic-ϕ\displaystyle\int(d\epsilon^{T})(d\phi){\rm Det}{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{1/2}\delta({\Delta_{L}}_{0}\phi) (3.27)
=\displaystyle= ∫(d​ϵT)​(d​ϕ)​Det​ΔL0−1/2​δ​(ϕ)=∫(d​ϵT)​Det​ΔL0−1/2.𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇𝑑italic-ϕDetsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012𝛿italic-ϕ𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇DetsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012\displaystyle\int(d\epsilon^{T})(d\phi){\rm Det}{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{-1/2}\delta(\phi)=\int(d\epsilon^{T}){\rm Det}{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{-1/2}\ .

This is the correct result, but from this argument the metric-independence is not evident. To this end, we proceed as follows. We note that the gauge parameters ϵTsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇\epsilon^{T} and ϕitalic-ϕ\phi are the coordinates in the subgroup 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} and in the quotient space Q=𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓/𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑄𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓Q=\mathit{Diff}/\mathit{SDiff}, respectively. This quotient space can be identified with the space of volume-forms. Therefore we demand that the measure on the quotient space agrees with the measure on the volume forms. An infinitesimal change of volume form is a trace deformation of the metric. Thus the measure on volume-forms is (d​h)𝑑ℎ(dh) and VQ=∫(d​h)subscript𝑉𝑄𝑑ℎV_{Q}=\int(dh). Equation (3.5) implies that

(d​h)=(d​ϕ)​Det​ΔL0.𝑑ℎ𝑑italic-ϕDetsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0(dh)=(d\phi)\,{\rm Det}{\Delta_{L}}_{0}\ .

We can thus split (3.26) as follows

V𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓=∫(d​ϵ)=∫(d​ϵT)​detΔL0−1/2​∫(d​ϕ)​detΔL0=V𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓​VQ,subscript𝑉𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑑italic-ϵ𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇superscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012𝑑italic-ϕsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0subscript𝑉𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓subscript𝑉𝑄V_{\mathit{Diff}}=\int(d\epsilon)=\int(d\epsilon^{T})\det{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{-1/2}\int(d\phi)\det{\Delta_{L}}_{0}=V_{\mathit{SDiff}}V_{Q}\ ,

where

V𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓=∫(d​ϵT)​Det​ΔL0−1/2.subscript𝑉𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇DetsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012V_{\mathit{SDiff}}=\int(d\epsilon^{T}){\rm Det}{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{-1/2}\ . (3.28)

Now V𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓subscript𝑉𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓V_{\mathit{SDiff}} is seen to be the ratio of V𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓subscript𝑉𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓V_{\mathit{Diff}} and VQsubscript𝑉𝑄V_{Q}, both of which are integrals over unconstrained variables and hence metric-independent. Thus this definition of V𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓subscript𝑉𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓V_{\mathit{SDiff}} is metric-independent.888At this point one may wonder whether in (3.22) we should also have inserted detΔL0−1/2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012\det{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{-1/2}. This would have led to a factor detΔL01/2superscriptsubscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿012\det{\Delta_{L}}_{0}^{1/2} in ΨΨ\Psi, and these two determinants would cancel out in the path integral. This is also the expected result, because with this measure we can rewrite (3.25) as

ZU​G=V𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓​e−S​(g¯)​Det1​(ΔL​1−2​R¯d)1/2Det2​(ΔL​2−2​R¯d)1/2.subscript𝑍𝑈𝐺subscript𝑉𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓superscript𝑒𝑆¯𝑔subscriptDet1superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿12¯𝑅𝑑12subscriptDet2superscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿22¯𝑅𝑑12Z_{UG}=V_{\mathit{SDiff}}e^{-S(\bar{g})}\frac{{\rm Det}_{1}\left(\Delta_{L1}-\frac{2\bar{R}}{d}\right)^{1/2}}{{\rm Det}_{2}\left(\Delta_{L2}-\frac{2\bar{R}}{d}\right)^{1/2}}\ . Apart from the volume of the gauge group, that we can now drop, the result is identical to the partition function for GR.

3.3 One-loop UG with Weyl invariance

We now consider the form (1.7) for the UG action. The quantum field is now the unrestricted metric γμ​νsubscript𝛾𝜇𝜈\gamma_{\mu\nu} and in the background field expansion we have the option of using either the exponential or the more traditional linear splitting. Let us discuss first the case of the exponential parametrization. Since the trace and tracefree parts of the fluctuation hμ​νsubscriptℎ𝜇𝜈h_{\mu\nu} commute, we can write

γμ​ν=e1d​hg~μ​ν,g~μ​ν=g¯μ​ρ(exp(hT))ρν\gamma_{\mu\nu}=e^{\frac{1}{d}h}\tilde{g}_{\mu\nu}\ ,\qquad\tilde{g}_{\mu\nu}=\bar{g}_{\mu\rho}\left(\exp(h^{T})\right)^{\rho}{}_{\nu} (3.30)

where hTsuperscriptℎ𝑇h^{T} is a traceless matrix and hℎh is a function. The determinant of the metric γμ​νsubscript𝛾𝜇𝜈\gamma_{\mu\nu} is

detγ=eh​detg~=eh​detg¯=eh​ω2.𝛾superscript𝑒ℎ~𝑔superscript𝑒ℎ¯𝑔superscript𝑒ℎsuperscript𝜔2\det\gamma=e^{h}\det\tilde{g}=e^{h}\det\bar{g}=e^{h}\omega^{2}\ . (3.31)

Then,

|γ|−1​∇|γ|=∇h+2​ω−1​∇ωsuperscript𝛾1∇𝛾∇ℎ2superscript𝜔1∇𝜔|\gamma|^{-1}\nabla|\gamma|=\nabla h+2\omega^{-1}\nabla\omega

and the integrand of (1.7) becomes:

ω​e1d​h​[R​[γ]+(d−1)​(d−2)​(∂12​d​h)2]=ω​R​[g~]𝜔superscript𝑒1𝑑ℎdelimited-[]𝑅delimited-[]𝛾𝑑1𝑑2superscript12𝑑ℎ2𝜔𝑅delimited-[]~𝑔\omega e^{\frac{1}{d}h}\left[R[\gamma]+(d-1)(d-2)(\partial\frac{1}{2d}h)^{2}\right]=\omega\,R[\tilde{g}]

so that

S​(γ)=ZN​∫dd​x​ω​R​[g~].𝑆𝛾subscript𝑍𝑁superscript𝑑𝑑𝑥𝜔𝑅delimited-[]~𝑔S(\gamma)=Z_{N}\int d^{d}x\,\omega\,R[\tilde{g}]\ . (3.32)

It is now clear that in the expansion of the action (1.7) the trace hℎh cancels completely, and the rest is exactly as the expansion of the action (1.3). Without any further calculation, we conclude that the effective action is the same.

In linear parametrization, a more detailed calculation is required. Writing

γμ​ν=g¯μ​ν+hμ​νsubscript𝛾𝜇𝜈subscript¯𝑔𝜇𝜈subscriptℎ𝜇𝜈\gamma_{\mu\nu}=\bar{g}_{\mu\nu}+h_{\mu\nu} (3.33)

the Hessian of (1.7) is [14]

S𝑆\displaystyle S\!\! =\displaystyle= ZN∫ddx|g¯|{14hμ​ν∇¯2hμ​ν−12hμ​ν∇¯μ∇¯ρhρ​ν+1dh∇¯μ∇¯νhμ​ν−d+24​d2h∇¯2h\displaystyle\!\!Z_{N}\!\int d^{d}x\,\sqrt{|\bar{g}|}\Bigg{\{}\frac{1}{4}h_{\mu\nu}\bar{\nabla}^{2}h^{\mu\nu}-\frac{1}{2}h_{\mu\nu}\bar{\nabla}^{\mu}\bar{\nabla}_{\rho}h^{\rho\nu}+\frac{1}{d}h\bar{\nabla}_{\mu}\bar{\nabla}_{\nu}h^{\mu\nu}-\frac{d+2}{4d^{2}}h\bar{\nabla}^{2}h (3.34)
+12hμ​νR¯μ​ρ​ν​σhρ​σ+12hμ​νR¯μ​ρhρ−ν1dhR¯ρ​σhρ​σ−12​d(hμ​νhμ​ν−1dh2)R¯}.\displaystyle+\frac{1}{2}h_{\mu\nu}\bar{R}^{\mu\rho\nu\sigma}h_{\rho\sigma}+\frac{1}{2}h_{\mu\nu}\bar{R}^{\mu\rho}h_{\rho}{}^{\nu}-\frac{1}{d}h\bar{R}^{\rho\sigma}h_{\rho\sigma}-\frac{1}{2d}\left(h_{\mu\nu}h^{\mu\nu}-\frac{1}{d}h^{2}\right)\bar{R}\Bigg{\}}\,.

For Euclidean signature, assuming an Einstein background and rewriting in terms of the Lichnerowicz Laplacians

S=ZN​∫dd​x​g¯​[14​hμ​ν​Δ¯2​hμ​ν−12​∇¯μ​hμ​ν​∇¯ρ​hρ​ν−1d​h​∇¯μ​∇¯ν​hμ​ν−d+24​d2​h​Δ¯0​h−12​d​R¯​(hμ​ν2−1d​h2)]𝑆subscript𝑍𝑁superscript𝑑𝑑𝑥¯𝑔delimited-[]14subscriptℎ𝜇𝜈subscript¯Δ2superscriptℎ𝜇𝜈12superscript¯∇𝜇subscriptℎ𝜇𝜈subscript¯∇𝜌superscriptℎ𝜌𝜈1𝑑ℎsubscript¯∇𝜇subscript¯∇𝜈superscriptℎ𝜇𝜈𝑑24superscript𝑑2ℎsubscript¯Δ0ℎ12𝑑¯𝑅superscriptsubscriptℎ𝜇𝜈21𝑑superscriptℎ2S\!\!=\!\!Z_{N}\!\int d^{d}x\,\sqrt{\bar{g}}\Bigg{[}\frac{1}{4}h_{\mu\nu}\bar{\Delta}_{2}h^{\mu\nu}-\frac{1}{2}\bar{\nabla}^{\mu}h_{\mu\nu}\bar{\nabla}_{\rho}h^{\rho\nu}-\frac{1}{d}h\bar{\nabla}_{\mu}\bar{\nabla}_{\nu}h^{\mu\nu}-\frac{d+2}{4d^{2}}h\bar{\Delta}_{0}h-\frac{1}{2d}\bar{R}\left(h_{\mu\nu}^{2}-\frac{1}{d}h^{2}\right)\Bigg{]} (3.35)

This Hessian has a kernel consisting of infinitesimal diffeos and infinitesimal Weyl transformations. We can then fix the gauge h=0ℎ0h=0 for the Weyl group. This leaves no ghosts, because hℎh transforms by a shift. Using the York decomposition for the remaining traceless fluctuation leads back exactly to (3.9). For 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} we can fix the same gauge as in section 2.1, so that the result for the effective action is again the same.

3.4 Four dimensions

The effective action is related to the partition function by Z​(g¯)=e−Γ​(g¯)𝑍¯𝑔superscript𝑒Γ¯𝑔Z(\bar{g})=e^{-\Gamma(\bar{g})}. Neglecting field-independent terms, we find indifferently from (3.18) or (3.29):

Γ​(g¯)=S​(g¯)+12​log⁡Det​(ΔL​2−2​R¯d)−12​log⁡Det​(ΔL​1−2​R¯d).Γ¯𝑔𝑆¯𝑔12DetsubscriptΔ𝐿22¯𝑅𝑑12DetsubscriptΔ𝐿12¯𝑅𝑑\Gamma(\bar{g})=S(\bar{g})+\frac{1}{2}\log{\rm Det}\left(\Delta_{L2}-\frac{2\bar{R}}{d}\right)-\frac{1}{2}\log{\rm Det}\left(\Delta_{L1}-\frac{2\bar{R}}{d}\right)\ . (3.36)

The divergent part of the effective action can be computed by standard heat kernel methods [23]. On an Einstein background in four dimension the logarithmically divergent part is

Γl​o​g​(g¯)subscriptΓ𝑙𝑜𝑔¯𝑔\displaystyle\Gamma_{log}(\bar{g}) =\displaystyle= −12​(4​π)2​∫d4​x​g¯​log⁡(k2μ2)​(5345​R¯μ​ν​ρ​σ​R¯μ​ν​ρ​σ−2940​R2),12superscript4𝜋2superscript𝑑4𝑥¯𝑔superscript𝑘2superscript𝜇25345subscript¯𝑅𝜇𝜈𝜌𝜎superscript¯𝑅𝜇𝜈𝜌𝜎2940superscript𝑅2\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2(4\pi)^{2}}\int d^{4}x\,\sqrt{\bar{g}}\log\left(\frac{k^{2}}{\mu^{2}}\right)\left(\frac{53}{45}\bar{R}_{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}\bar{R}^{\mu\nu\rho\sigma}-\frac{29}{40}R^{2}\right)\,, (3.37)

where k𝑘k stands for a cutoff and we introduced a reference mass scale μ𝜇\mu. Replacing R→4​Λ→𝑅4ΛR\to 4\Lambda this agrees with the classic result of [24].

The result is independent of the gauge-fixing parameters α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta as expected in view of the fact that the Einstein condition is enough to put the background metric on shell.

4 Discussion

UG and GR are known to be almost identical at the classical level. Besides the equations of motion, this has been seen also in the tree-level amplitudes [25, 26]. The question is then whether this persists when loop effects are taken into account. In this paper we provide further evidence for the equivalence of the two theories. The main subtlety arises in the definition of the path integral for UG. Since this is tied closely to implementing the proper count of degrees of freedom, let us review quickly how this works, starting from the classical theory.

In GR, as in Yang-Mils theory, the number of physical degrees of freedom is equal to the number of fields minus twice the number of gauge parameters (“the gauge strikes twice”). For example, in four-dimensional gravity we have 10 fields hμ​νsubscriptℎ𝜇𝜈h_{\mu\nu} and four gauge parameters (the components of a vector field ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) yielding two propagating degrees of freedom. In UG we have nine components for hμ​νsubscriptℎ𝜇𝜈h_{\mu\nu} (which is tracefree) and three gauge parameters (the components of a transverse vector field ϵTsuperscriptitalic-ϵ𝑇\epsilon^{T}) so the general rule would seem to give three propagating degrees of freedom. The general rule does not apply in this case because the gauge parameter is subject to the differential constraint (3.19).

For a correct counting it is best to go back to the Hamiltonian formulation. GR has 10 Lagrangian variables and 4 Lagrangian gauge parameters, equivalently 20 Hamiltonian variables and 8 first class constraints (i.e. 8 gauge parameters). Each of these removes two Hamiltonian variables: one is removed by the constraint itself and one by the corresponding gauge condition. Thus one is left with 20−2×8=42028420-2\times 8=4 canonical variables, corresponding to the 2 physical polarization states of the graviton. In UG there are 9 fields and 3 Lagrangian gauge parameters, giving rise to 6 constraints, but there is also a “tertiary” constraint bringing the number of first class constraints to 7. With 18 Hamiltonian variables and 7 first class constraints, we have again 18−2×7=41827418-2\times 7=4 physical canonical variables. Using “unitary” gauges, all this can be easily implemented in the Hamiltonian path integrals, showing that they are the same for GR and UG. The price one has to pay for this simple count is the lack of explicit covariance.

In the classical Lagrangian formulation of UG, when we use York variables, the gauge condition (3.21) removes ξμsubscript𝜉𝜇\xi_{\mu} and there seems to be a leftover unphysical scalar degree of freedom σ𝜎\sigma. However, among the generators of 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff}, there is a subclass that is generated by vector fields that are, so to speak, “simultaneously longitudinal and transverse”: these are the vector fields of the form ϵμ=∇μϕsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇subscript∇𝜇italic-ϕ\epsilon_{\mu}=\nabla_{\mu}\phi with ΔL0​ϕ=0subscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0italic-ϕ0{\Delta_{L}}_{0}\phi=0.999These transformations are analogous to the residual gauge transformation satisfying ∂2ϵμ=0superscript2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝜇0\partial^{2}\epsilon_{\mu}=0, when one imposes the de Donder condition. The scalar σ𝜎\sigma transforms by a shift and when it is on shell it can be removed by such a transformation, restoring the correct counting.101010We note that the count of degrees of freedom has to be done in Lorentzian signature, where the kernel of ΔL0subscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0{\Delta_{L}}_{0} is an infinite-dimensional space, parametrized by all the fields ϕitalic-ϕ\phi on an initial spacelike hypersurface. On a compact Euclidean manifold without boundary the kernel of ΔL0subscriptsubscriptΔ𝐿0{\Delta_{L}}_{0} consists only of the constants.

In the path integral this issue manifests itself as a nontrivial scalar determinant left over by the integration on the field σ𝜎\sigma (see the denominator of (3.25)). We have shown that this determinant is part of the measure on the group 𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑆𝐷𝑖𝑓𝑓\mathit{SDiff} and therefore does not appear in the “physical” terms in the final formula for the partition function.

We have framed this discussion in the context of a one-loop definition of the path integral. However, the main point concerned the definition of the path integral measure. Insofar as the path integrals embody all quantum effects, they are the same for GR and UG. This is in accordance with the conclusions of [9, 7] for the perturbative expansion, and [8] for the fully diffeomorphism-invariant version of UG. Our results also agree with the result of [6] that the effective action of UG is still a functional of an unimodular metric. One could try to make a non-perturbative statement by using the functional renormalization group equations.111111In particular it would be interesting to compare the well-established Effective Average Action formalism [27] to a proper-time flow equation [28] whose exact version for the Wilsonian action has been discussed recently [29].

The preceding discussion was entirely in the context of the “minimal” formulation based on the exponential parametrization, where GR is the quantum theory of a symmetric tensor and UG is the quantum theory of a traceless symmetric tensor. We have shown that the equivalence also holds in the formulation in which the metric is unconstrained but there is an additional Weyl symmetry. In this formulation, a scalar degree of freedom is removed by imposing a Weyl gauge condition and the equivalence between UG and GR at the quantum level hinges on the absence of Weyl anomalies. In this connection we observe that if we define a scalar field

ϕ2=ω2/d|γ|1/dsuperscriptitalic-ϕ2superscript𝜔2𝑑superscript𝛾1𝑑\phi^{2}=\frac{\omega^{2/d}}{|\gamma|^{1/d}}

then equation (1.7) becomes the usual action for a conformally coupled scalar. The absence of Weyl anomalies in such theories has been proven in [31, 32], see also [33, 34].

With regards to the question left open in [20], whether the limit m→−1/d→𝑚1𝑑m\to-1/d is continuous, we find that the answer is positive.

Concerning the problem of the cosmological constant, the classical conclusion that vacuum energy does not gravitate extends to the quantum theory. As already noted in [6], this follows from the fact that the effective action will also be “unimodular”, so that the cosmological term appears in the equations as an arbitrary integration constant. This holds independently whether the quantum theory is viewed merely as an effective field theory or has an UV completion as in asymptotic safety. The quantum treatment would be relevant even if it turned out that gravity is “emergent” [30]. A unimodular effective action eliminates the “prediction” that spacetime should have Planckian curvature, but it does not explain why it has the observed value, if we assume that the observed cosmic acceleration is due to a cosmological term.
